s1.p: Video formats combine container formats and codecs—container acts as wrapper holding video, audio, and metadata, while codec compresses and decompresses video data. MP4 container with H.264 codec dominates web and mobile due to wide compatibility and excellent compression. WebM combines WebP video codec with Vorbis audio, optimized for web but less universally supported. MOV/QuickTime originated on Mac but works cross-platform. AVI is older format with larger files but still used for archival. Understanding this distinction helps you choose appropriate formats for different platforms and purposes.

s2.p: MP4 works best for most web video, streaming platforms (YouTube, Netflix), and mobile devices due to excellent compatibility and efficient compression. WebM suits web-only projects where universal support isn't necessary and file size matters. MKV container handles high-quality video with multiple audio tracks, perfect for movies and complex projects. MOV works well for Mac-native workflows and professional editing. GIF serves short animations and memes in web contexts. Choose formats based on target platform, device compatibility requirements, and quality needs.

s3.p: Always convert from the highest quality source available to preserve image quality. Converting from already-compressed video degrades quality further. Most video conversions are lossy, meaning each conversion cycle loses data. Higher bitrates maintain quality but increase file size. Balance quality and file size based on intended use—streaming video needs smaller files, archive video prioritizes quality. Test conversion settings on sample clips before processing entire videos. Use hardware acceleration for faster conversion when available, though quality should always take priority over speed.

s4.p: Bitrate controls data density and directly impacts video quality and file size. 1080p video typically uses 5000-8000 kbps for streaming, 8000-15000 kbps for higher quality. 720p uses 2500-4500 kbps for streaming. Mobile video often uses 800-1500 kbps. Higher bitrates preserve more detail but create larger files. Match bitrate to resolution—4K video at low bitrate looks worse than 1080p at appropriate bitrate. Experiment with settings for your specific content, as different material (animation vs. live action) compresses differently. Use progressive bitrate encoding for online video to adapt to user bandwidth.

s5.p: Video conversions should preserve or optimize audio separately from video. Most video conversions use stereo audio at 128-256 kbps for quality streaming. Mono audio at 64-96 kbps works for voice-only content. Preserve 5.1 or 7.1 surround sound in higher-quality conversions for home theater. AAC audio codec offers good quality-to-filesize ratio and works across platforms. MP3 audio is older but universally compatible. Ensure audio levels are normalized to prevent distortion. Test audio quality separately after conversion to verify clarity and volume levels.

s6.p: Batch processing saves time when converting multiple videos. Organize source videos by format and quality before batch processing. Apply same settings to all videos in a batch, or create multiple batches for different settings. Start with small test batches to verify settings before committing large numbers of videos. Monitor conversion progress and verify output quality before finishing. Keep source files until you confirm conversion quality meets standards. Automated batch workflows help streamline large-scale video projects while maintaining quality control.
